text: Pakistan's prime minister Nawaz Sharif
has resigned after the country's Supreme
Court unanimously ruled that he should
be disqualified over corruption
allegations while the ruling follows
accusations relating to the Panama
papers published two years ago in which
mr. Sharif's three children were
implicated he and his family deny any
wrongdoing let's talk about this then
too our Pakistan correspondent Secunda
Kimani he joins me in the studio is this
a surprise as resignation well I think
after the unanimous Court decision
against him saying that recommending
that he was disqualified as qualifying
him from office I think the Prime
Minister had little little choice other
than other than to go if he hadn't have
gone in with quite likely seen mass
protests for example on on the streets I
mean this this issue this Panama paper
leaks case has been really dominating
Pakistani politics for well over the
last year and we've seen allegations
made against the Prime Minister Nawaz
Sharif and his children that they
according to an official inquiry
accumulated more wealth over the years
than their declared sources of income
could account for and they were quite
damning comments made by this official
inquiry and so having said that so in
some ways this wasn't a totally
unexpected however this is unprecedented
in Pakistan we've it's unprecedented
that a sitting Prime Minister faces this
level of scrutiny and then is removed
from office and we said that his party
the pml-n party are still in power they
will have the opportunity to nominate a
new leader next week it's not clear who
that could be it could there's been some
suggestion it could be his brother
although there's also objections to him

about what will happen then and so he's
resigned what will happen though is he
facing prosecution potentially well the
supreme court has said that a trial
should take place under the auspices of

it's called the national accountability
Bureau and that will look into the
allegations
that both he and his children
accumulated money basically through
corrupt practices and quite crucially
this trial that will take place will
place the burden of the proof on the
defendant so we'll place the burden of
proving that they had acquired this
money legitimately on the prime minister
and his children and an upper term now
the essence of why he's been
disqualified is really because the
judges say that he hasn't been able to
account for how he got the money they
say in effect there's no smoking gun
necessarily of exactly what kind of
practices were used or weren't used to
have totally earned this money but he
hasn't been able to account for it
properly and so he hadn't been honest
